data.title: Local music roundup: Aug. 8
data.meta_description: If you want to dance to the music of Ghana, buy tickets for the Occidental Dance Band International show at SPACE this Saturday.
data.text:
It’s prime vacation time and lots of our fellow Evanston residents are out of town. This means you might get better seats for the excellent musical events coming up this week! If you want to dance to the music of Ghana (and other African nations), buy tickets for the Occidental Dance Band International show at SPACE this Saturday. If you want to laugh your head off, go see The Nobodies at Cary’s Lounge in Chicago this Saturday. Evanston’s favorite soul/funk band, Chicken Bone, will play an outdoor concert Tuesday, Aug. 13 at James Park. As always, our local music scene offers a plethora of choices!

Thursday, Aug. 8

Petra van Nuis, Morning Music, 10 a.m. at the McGinley Pavillion, Chicago Botanic Garden, 1000 Lake Cook Road, Glencoe. The Chicago Botanic Garden has launched early concert series – great idea! Van Nuis is a jazz vocalist with a light, delicate voice. She’s very active in Chicago, playing major venues like the Jazz Showcase, and she often works with her husband, jazz guitarist Andy Brown.

Mixx Company Band 5 p.m. at Fountain Square in downtown Evanston. This outdoor concert is part of the Downtown Summer Sounds series. The Mixx Company Band was founded by drummer and band leader Terrell Carter. The band performs excellent R&B soul, smooth jazz, blues, pop and rock. In addition to performing as a headliner, Mixx Company supports many other artists (both local and touring acts). These musicians put on a great show! Free admission.

Gandy Gumbo 7 p.m. at The Fat Shallot, 2902 Central St. Gandy Gumbo is a trio (Albie Powers, Mark Blank and Dean “Deano” Harris) that plays a mix of Americana, blues and folk music including several original songs. This is primarily an acoustic group, but they do have a drummer. Free admission.

Ben Paterson Organ Trio, 7 p.m. at Le Piano, 6970 N Glenwood Ave., Chicago. Downbeat Magazine said Paterson is “as soulful a pianist/organist as exists anywhere.” He played for several years with the great Chicago tenor sax player Von Freeman. Paterson also has a wonderful singing voice. LePiano has a Hammond B3 organ performance every Thursday evening. $15.

Two Pianos, Four Hands, 7:30 p.m. at North Shore Center for the Performing Arts, 9501 Skokie Blvd., Skokie. Northlight Theater is presenting this music and comedy show that features pianists Richard Greenblatt and Ted Dykstra. This duo of would-be concert pianists trade stories of pushy parents, eccentric teachers, endless practice and dreams of stardom. Piano wizardry and roaring comedy combine as “piano nerds” Ted and Richard play classical, pop and everything in between, all while portraying dozens of characters who took part in their humbling quest for musical greatness. This show runs through Aug. 11. $56/$76.

Sondheim Tribute Revue, 7:30 p.m. at the Skokie Theater, 7924 Lincoln Ave., Skokie. This show is a production of the 4 Chairs Theater. An ensemble of six singers will perform the works of the legendary Stephen Sondheim. Sondheim won an Academy Award, eight Tony Awards (more than any other composer) including the Special Tony Award for Lifetime Achievement in the Theatre, multiple Grammy Awards, multiple Drama Desk awards and a Pulitzer Prize. $35.

Holly Bowling, 8 p.m. at SPACE, 1245 Chicago Ave. Bowling is a remarkable pianist popular with fans of the Grateful Dead and Phish. She plays solo piano versions of their music, including their live concert improvisational work. This young woman started playing piano at the age of 5 and released her first album in 2015. Bowling also plays with Phil Lesh & Friends and Greensky Bluegrass. Bowling is working to keep the Grateful Dead alive! $25/$35.

Blue Ether, 8 p.m. at Double Clutch Brewing, 2121 Ashland Ave. Blue Ether is a Chicago-based group that came together during the pandemic. The band’s music is a mash-up of alternative rock and punk rock – they have a lead vocalist backed by a power trio (guitar, bass, drums). Free.

Friday, Aug. 9

Reggae Music Night, 7 p.m. at Good To Go Jamaican Cuisine, 711 Howard St. Lenice and Tony Levy have created a marvelous destination for Jamaican food and reggae music. Tony is from Jamaica and has said “I want to bring Jamaica here!” Music happens every Friday night – the Hurricane Reggae Band is one of the regular bands. Free.

Chad Willetts Quartet, 7 p.m. at Le Piano, 6970 N Glenwood Ave., Chicago. Willetts is a drummer, pianist and owner/operator of this excellent East Rogers Park jazz club/restaurant. His jazz quartet features a guest artist every Friday night. $15.

Two Pianos, Four Hands, 7:30 p.m. at North Shore Center for the Performing Arts, 9501 Skokie Blvd., Skokie. Northlight Theater is presenting this music and comedy show that features pianists Richard Greenblatt and Ted Dykstra. See listing for Aug. 8 for further information. This show runs through Aug. 11. $56/$75.

Sondheim Tribute Revue, 7:30 p.m. at the Skokie Theater, 7924 Lincoln Ave., Skokie. This show is a production of the 4 Chairs Theater. An ensemble of six singers will perform the works of the legendary Stephen Sondheim. Sondheim won an Academy Award, eight Tony Awards (more than any other composer) including the Special Tony Award for Lifetime Achievement in the Theatre, multiple Grammy Awards, multiple Drama Desk awards and a Pulitzer Prize. $35.

Albert Lee & Jeremy Clyde, 8 p.m. at SPACE, 1245 Chicago Ave. For all of the folks old enough (and clear-minded enough) to remember the 1960s, this is your show. Clyde was one half of the duo, Chad & Jeremy. They were part of the 1964 “British Invasion” that brought the Beatles and others to the U.S. Chad & Jeremy had seven Top 40 hits in the 1960s, including Yesterday’s Gone. Albert Lee is a killer guitarist who has supported many stars (including Joe Cocker and Eric Clapton). He also served as music director for the Everly Brothers for 25 years. This show will be a combination of old hits, new tunes and stories from the colorful careers of these two senior musicians. $20/$35.

The Racket, 8 p.m. at Double Clutch Brewing, 2121 Ashland Ave. The Racket brings its unique acoustic-electric multi-vocalist sound to a wide range of familiar rock/indie classics, among them Tom Petty, REM, Cracker, Caamp, Grateful Dead, Neil Young, Phish, Big Head Todd and others. Free admission.

Christy Bennett, 11 p.m. at Le Piano, 6970 Glenwood Ave., Chicago. Bennett is a busy jazz vocalist who performs a late-night set at Le Piano every Friday night. She is accompanied by Kevin Fort on piano. $15.

Saturday, Aug. 10

Two Pianos, Four Hands, 2:30 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. at North Shore Center for the Performing Arts, 9501 Skokie Blvd., Skokie. Northlight Theater is presenting this music and comedy show that features pianists Richard Greenblatt and Ted Dykstra. See listing for Aug. 8 for further information. This show runs through Aug. 11. $56/$75.

Blue Lorraine Quartet, 4 p.m. at Cary’s Lounge, 2251 Devon Ave., Chicago. This band plays that good ol’ country music! Linda Weseman – guitar & vocals, Jason Batchko – drums, Josh Piet – bass and Gabriel Stuta – pedal steel guitar. Free admission.

Chad Willetts Quartet, 7 p.m. at Le Piano, 6970 N Glenwood Ave., Chicago. Willetts is a drummer, pianist, and owner/operator of this excellent East Rogers Park jazz club/restaurant. His Saturday night quartet features Dez Desormeaux on tenor sax. Desormeaux has that full-throated Chicago tenor sax tone! $15.

Sondheim Tribute Revue, 7:30 p.m. at the Skokie Theater, 7924 Lincoln Ave., Skokie. This show is a production of the 4 Chairs Theater. An ensemble of six singers will perform the works of the legendary Stephen Sondheim. Sondheim won an Academy Award, eight Tony Awards (more than any other composer) including the Special Tony Award for Lifetime Achievement in the Theatre, multiple Grammy Awards, multiple Drama Desk awards and a Pulitzer Prize. $35.

Occidental Brothers Dance Band Int’l, 8 p.m. at SPACE, 1245 Chicago Ave. This is definitely music that forces you to dance! The Occidental Brothers Dance Band Int’l are celebrating their 20th year as Chicago’s premier African jazz and Ghananian Highlife music group. They have just released a new album and will play tunes from the new release. $15/$25.

The Nobodies, 8:30 p.m. at Cary’s Lounge, 2251 W. Devon, Chicago. This band’s promotional material says “These jerks will annoy you, entertain you, and drive you to drink.” They are hilarious. Here is an example (warning – this clip is NSFW). Free.

Petra van Nuis, 11 p.m. at Le Piano, 6970 N Glenwood Ave., Chicago. Van Nuis is a jazz vocalist with a light, delicate voice who performs the late-night set at Le Piano every Saturday. She’s very active in Chicago and often works with her husband, jazz guitarist Andy Brown. Pianist Dennis “Deluxe” Luxon accompanies van Nuis during the late-night set at Le Piano. $15.

Sunday, Aug. 11

Ingrid Graudins: Memorial Benefit Show, 1 p.m. at SPACE, 1245 Chicago Ave. Graudins passed away Jan. 9. She was a beloved member of the singer/songwriter community in Chicago and Nashville and a frequent performer at Evanston SPACE and many other venues in the Chicago area. In addition to her own stunning performances, she was cherished for her efforts to nurture the careers of other musicians. This memorial benefit will feature a large group of Graudins’ colleagues, friends and collaborators, including the popular and talented singer/songwriter Nora O’Connor and standout guitarist Chris Siebold. Proceeds from ticket sales will benefit selected local animal shelters, reflecting Graudins’ lifelong commitment to animal welfare. $15/$25.

Two Pianos, Four Hands, 2:30 p.m. at North Shore Center for the Performing Arts, 9501 Skokie Blvd., Skokie. Northlight Theater is presenting this music and comedy show that features pianists Richard Greenblatt and Ted Dykstra. See listing for Aug. 1 for further information. This show runs through Aug. 11. $56/$75.

Sondheim Tribute Revue, 3 p.m. at the Skokie Theater, 7924 Lincoln Ave., Skokie. This show is a production of the 4 Chairs Theater. An ensemble of six singers will perform the works of the legendary Stephen Sondheim. Sondheim won an Academy Award, eight Tony Awards (more than any other composer) including the Special Tony Award for Lifetime Achievement in the Theatre, multiple Grammy Awards, multiple Drama Desk awards and a Pulitzer Prize. $35.

Annalee Koehn with Chuck Cox and Aaron Smith, 4 p.m. at Sketchbook Brewing, 4901 Main St., Skokie. Koehn is an acoustic guitarist and vocalist. She teams up with long-time collaberators Cox and Smith to deliver folk songs with pleasing vocal harmonies. Free.

Victor Brown Band, 7 p.m. at Double Clutch Brewing, 2121 Ashland Ave. This seven-piece group covers the Grateful Dead, the Allman Brothers and other jam bands. They know how to provide a party soundtrack! Free admission.

Generations of Chicago Blues, Ben Levin and Bob Stroger with special guest Dave Specter, 7 p.m. at SPACE, 1245 Chicago Ave. Levin is a Cincinnati-based pianist and vocalist who pounds out that two-fisted stride blues piano. He has collaborated with many blues artists including Chicago’s L’il Ed Williams. Stroger is a super-senior. At 94, he is still one of the best and busiest bass players in the Chicago blues community. He has played with so many legendary blues musicians, from Sunnyland Slim to Otis Rush to Koko Taylor. Specter is a fine blues guitarist (Delmark Records artist) and promoter (he was one of the founders and part-owners of SPACE). $15/$25.

Amr Fahmy Trio, 7 p.m. at Le Piano, 6970 N Glenwood Ave., Chicago. Fahmy is the pianist for the Chicago Soul Jazz Collective, a hard-grooving group of top-notch musicians who often perform with the marvelous vocalist Dee Alexander. He brings his trio to Le Piano every Sunday. $15.

Monday, Aug. 12

Tony Furtado, 7:30 p.m. at SPACE, 1245 Chicago Ave. Furtado is a singer/songwriter/multi-instrumentalist based in Portland, Oregon. He has been a major figure in Americana music since 1990. Furtado has a unique and excellent voice and is a virtuoso player of several instruments (including banjo, guitar and baritone ukulele). $18/$25.

Tuesday, Aug. 13

Chicken Bone, 6:30 p.m. at James Park, 300 Dodge Ave. This is part of Evanston’s Starlight Concert series. Chicken Bone is Evanston’s own 10-piece funk/rock/soul band. The group will be covering favorite songs from the 1960s through today. Chicken Bone is a locally famous party and dance band!

Irish Music Session, 7 p.m. at Sketchbook Brewing Evanston, 821 Chicago Ave. Traditional Irish music session with a shifting cast of players; Sketchbook owner Shawn Decker usually brings his fiddle and joins in the session. Folks who can play Irish music can join in! Free.

Cabaret Night featuring Nitz and Friends North, 7 p.m. at Le Piano, 6970 N Glenwood Ave., Chicago. Daryl Nitz has been performing and producing cabaret shows in Chicago for years while teaching for 30 years in Chicago area public schools. He retired last year from his teaching career and is devoting his full efforts to his art. This is a recurring show every Tuesday night. $15.

Elephant Sessions, 7:30 p.m. at SPACE, 1245 Chicago Ave. Elephant Sessions is a Scottish indie rock and folk band that formed in 2012. This group amplifies traditional folk instruments (mandolin and fiddle) and backs them with a rock rhythm section. Their songs are complex and engaging. $15/$25.

Open blues jam, 8 p.m. at Fritzy’s Tavern, 6156 Clark St., Chicago. We have no open blues jams in Evanston – the Tuesday night jam at the defunct Bill’s Blues Bar was epic, but it’s gone. This jam is a 10-minute drive from Evanston’s southern border, and it’s worth the trip. The “jam master” is Ed Genne, a solid blues guitarist, and a fine human being. Fritzy’s is owned by Karen King, a tenacious small businesswoman who managed to keep her bar from dying during COVID. The drinks are reasonably priced and the jammers are often amazingly talented. Free.

Wednesday, Aug. 14

Istvan & His Imaginary Band, 10 a.m. at The Wallae Bowl, Gillson Park, 800 Gillson Park Dr., Wilmette. This event is not in Evanston, but it isn’t that far away and it’s a show for kids (and their parents). Istvan is a solid musician and a creative songwriter who knows how to engage with the younger set. This will be an outdoor event unless it rains – then it will be canceled. Free.

Donovan Mixon Band, 6 p.m., Concerts on Ridge at Ridgeville Park, 908 Seward St. This fine jazz guitarist has enriched Evanston with many local concerts, including his Donovan’s Garage series. Free.

The Tim Fitzgerald Guitar Trio, 7 p.m. at Le Piano, 6970 N Glenwood Ave., Chicago. Fitzgerald is a skilled guitarist heavily influenced by jazz great Wes Montgomery. Organist Tom Vaitsas often joins Fitzgerald. This is a recurring show on Wednesday nights. $15.

The Happy Time Orchestra, 7:30 p.m. at SPACE, 1245 Chicago Ave. This nine-piece group was launched in the depths of the pandemic when pianist/harmonica player got together with drummer/composer Collin Nordine to relieve the gloom of COVID. The band didn’t play a live concert until two years ago. The rest of the group is made up of some of the finest musicians in Chicago, including the killer trumpet/fluglehorn player Victor Garcia. The group plays original compositions only, and the music is unique. $25/$35.

Urban Horizons, 9 p.m. at Prairie Moon,1635 Chicago Ave. Guitarist Rahsaan Nance formed Urban Horizons in 2019. His group has a shifting cast of players and they play an exciting form of post-bop jazz. Nance will bring a quartet to Prairie Moon, including Garret Munz – alto saxophone, Leo Buckzowski – bass and Noah Sherman – drums $7.

Chris Gillock is a blues harmonica player, vocalist, non-profit board member and retired investment banker. He is also an occasional blogger – you can find his blog at https://g-freethoughts.blogspot.com/.... More by Chris Gillock
